item.title: Academic Review 2024
item.description: I am very passionate about physics, turns out that being passionate does not equate to being great at teaching it. I was excited at the thought of teaching Physics, a thing that I’m very passionate about and what I’m studying currently. I’ve prepared my carefully created slides along with a funny intro, a bunch of physics topics, and some quizzes along the way. I was very prepared for it.
item.content:
I am very passionate about physics, turns out that being passionate does not equate to being great at teaching it.

I was excited at the thought of teaching Physics, a thing that I’m very passionate about and what I’m studying currently. I’ve prepared my carefully created slides along with a funny intro, a bunch of physics topics, and some quizzes along the way. I was very prepared for it.

The very first day was just an opening event, along with their Pre-test during the afternoon. It was all very successful and my enthusiasm is very high imagining teaching those kids physics, hopefully igniting their spirits into studying physics and enjoying it more. I even hope that there’s some student that I could hopefully inspire to take up Physics as their degree program.

The day finally came where I would be teaching. I started with my funny intro (I definitely think it is funny), and started teaching. The first topic was Scalars and Vectors which is easily grasped by students and I see them actively participating on answering which is which. The next is vector addition. We started with one dimension where you can just add or subtract them. Then the 2D vectors came in where you’re going to use the Pythagorean theorem for it. I thought that this would be easy for them as it is just basic trigonometry but I was surprised that some students don’t know it (I’m looking at you DepEd). I taught some trigonometry crash course for a second but this is just a foreshadowing of problems to come.

We passed on some more trigonometry which I can sense that the students can’t fully grasp, which is a problem considering that physics is very math-heavy. We moved on to Motion which started with some definitions of some terms in which my students can finally understand again. The difference of distance and displacement is easy, then speed and displacement, which started some equations once more and I can see that the students are grasping very little of it, then we go to UARM, which was literally just equations. I can see that almost no one understands it at a glance. It’s a problem that I didn’t expect since this event was supposed to be a crash course of physics, not me teaching physics from scratch. I thought that this would be easy, but it was very far from that.

From there, we delved into more equations, in which I try to explain in a “physical sense” and not in “equation form” to at least let them grasp the topic a little. But I can see that only few are actively listening and maybe one or two actually understands what I’m teaching. My motivation, from very high is now so low. After I finished teaching one section, I expected that the other two sections that I’ll be teaching will be the same.

I messed up.

I should’ve focused more on things that they could understand and focused on it instead of dumping them with all the knowledge that I understand but they wouldn’t understand. I tried to fix my teaching in the other two sections but still, what I prepared was a mess. I couldn’t let them understand it. Albert Einstein said it himself, “If you can’t explain it to a six-year-old, you don’t understand it yourself”. What more that I can’t teach high school students basic physics? I recieved some comments that I was intelligent, that they couldn’t understand what I’m saying. I took that as a blow. I failed as a lecturer. It was a wake up call for me that I failed. I was ashamed of myself but what could I do?

I partly blame the education in the Philippines.

You might think that this is me just blaming others about my shortcomings, but I think students should at least know those topics because I’ve been in high school too, and I’ve learned those in high school. Yes, I’m from a Science High School but the education needs to be the same for everybody. The education system must be changed. I’m also not blaming the teachers because they are also underpaid and overworked due to our system.

Despite those, I’m grateful for that opportunity because I learned a lot about myself and others. The next time that I’ll be teaching someone, I need to understand where are they coming from. What do they know? This failure taught me what I need to learn. There is indeed only success and learning, you only fail if you didn’t learn. I thought that I’ll be teaching kids physics before the event but I ended up learning about teaching.

Thank you, UP MINDOREÑOS for the opportunity and I also want to thank the students for trying to understand what I taught. I apologize for failing as a lecturer. Thank you, and I will be better the next time around.

item.description: How I install Arch Linux Pre-Installation Lang: zsh Copy 1ping archlinux.org 2 3timedatectl 4 5cfdisk /dev/sdx 6 7mkfs.ext4 /dev/root_partition 8mkswap /dev/swap_partition 9mkfs.fat -F 32 /dev/efi_system_partition 10 11mkdir -p /mnt/boot/efi 12 13mount /dev/rootpartition /mnt 14mount /dev/efi_system_partition /mnt/boot/efi 15swapon /dev/swap_partition Installation Lang: zsh Copy 1pacstrap -K /mnt base base-devel linux linux-firmware linux-headers sof-firmware nvim grub efibootmgr 2networkmanager plasma-desktop zsh reflector 3 4genfstab -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab 5 6arch-chroot /mnt Configuration Lang: bash Copy 1ln -sf /usr/shate/zoneinfo/Asia/Manila /etc/localtime 2 3hwclock --systohc edit /etc/locale.
item.content:
How I install Arch Linux

Pre-Installation

Lang: zsh 
 1ping archlinux.org
 2
 3timedatectl
 4
 5cfdisk /dev/sdx
 6
 7mkfs.ext4 /dev/root_partition
 8mkswap /dev/swap_partition
 9mkfs.fat -F 32 /dev/efi_system_partition
10
11mkdir -p /mnt/boot/efi
12
13mount /dev/rootpartition /mnt
14mount /dev/efi_system_partition /mnt/boot/efi
15swapon /dev/swap_partition

Installation

Lang: zsh 
1pacstrap -K /mnt base base-devel linux linux-firmware linux-headers sof-firmware nvim grub efibootmgr 
2networkmanager plasma-desktop zsh reflector
3
4genfstab -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab
5
6arch-chroot /mnt

Configuration

Lang: bash 
1ln -sf /usr/shate/zoneinfo/Asia/Manila /etc/localtime
2
3hwclock --systohc

edit /etc/locale.gen and uncomment en_US.UTF-8 UTF-8

Lang: bash 
1locale-gen

Create locale.conf file

Lang: bash 
1LANG=en_US.UTF-8

Create hostname file at /etc/hostname

Lang: bash 
1yourhostname
Lang: bash 
1passwd
2
3useradd -m -G wheel -s /bin/zsh <name>
4passwd <name>
5
6EDITOR=nvim visudo

uncomment wheel

enable services

Lang: bash 
1systemctl enable NetworkManager
2systemctl enable sddm !or whatever login manager
3
4! if on ssd
5systemctl enable fstrim.timer
Lang: bash 
1grub-install /dev/sdx
2grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg
3
4umount -a

Adding windows on grub or other OS

install os-prober

edit /etc/default/grub and uncomment GRUB_DISABLE_OS_PROBER=false

Lang: bash 
1grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg
Lang: zsh 
1umount -a 
2
3reboot

item.description: Testing math on this website Block equations Pythagorean Theorem \[a^2 + b^2 = c^2\] Time Dependent Schrodinger Equation \[\frac{-\hbar ^2}{2m} \frac{\partial^2 \Psi(x,t)}{\partial x^2} + V(x)\Psi(x,t) = i\hbar \frac{\partial\Psi(x,t)}{\partial t}\]
item.content:
Testing math on this website

Block equations

Pythagorean Theorem

\[a^2 + b^2 = c^2\]

Time Dependent Schrodinger Equation

\[\frac{-\hbar ^2}{2m} \frac{\partial^2 \Psi(x,t)}{\partial x^2} + V(x)\Psi(x,t) = i\hbar \frac{\partial\Psi(x,t)}{\partial t}\]

item.title: About
item.description: Welcome to my corner of the web! I’m Dinan, physics student. Here’s a glimpse into my journey: Background Since High School, I’ve been fascinated by physics because for me, it’s the real world. Everything in the world follows the laws of physics, Hence, studying physics = studying the world Education and Qualifications I am currently studying Applied Physics from University of the Philippines Los Baños. During my academic journey, I delved deep into chemical physics.
item.content:
Welcome to my corner of the web! I’m Dinan, physics student. Here’s a glimpse into my journey:

Background

Since High School, I’ve been fascinated by physics because for me, it’s the real world. Everything in the world follows the laws of physics, Hence, studying physics = studying the world

Education and Qualifications

I am currently studying Applied Physics from University of the Philippines Los Baños. During my academic journey, I delved deep into chemical physics. Additionally, I am studying for certifications in Cyber Security.

Passions and Interests

Beyond my endeavors, I’m passionate about video games, Formula 1, technology, and programming. I haven’t played sports that much but the last time was cycling. I hope to get back to cycling as soon as I can

Goal

My goal at the moment is graduate on my degree program. I believe in hardwork makes the dream work. Through my efforts, I strive to help in the technology and physics industry of my country. Sadly, I don’t think my country cares about those at the moment.

Why This Website

I created this website as a platform to have my expertise and knowledge be shared. Here, you’ll find my CV, along with my blog posts that share my insights about the world.

Get in Touch

I’m always eager to connect with fellow professionals, collaborate on projects, or simply have a meaningful conversation. Feel free to contact me at my email, dinanmariano@gmail.com.

Thank you for visiting my website! I hope you find it insightful and inspiring.
